canonical_explanation.text: Data handling is the process of collecting, organizing, and interpreting information. Data can be organized using tally marks and frequency tables to count occurrences. Pictographs use pictures or symbols to represent data, where each symbol may represent more than one unit. Bar graphs use rectangular bars of equal width to represent data, with the bar height (or length) proportional to the value. Interpreting data means reading graphs and tables to answer questions, compare values, and draw conclusions.
rules: Rule 1: A tally mark uses groups of five: four vertical strokes and a diagonal stroke for the fifth (||||).
Rule 2: In a pictograph, each symbol represents a fixed number of items (given by the key). Partial symbols represent proportional amounts.
Rule 3: In a bar graph, all bars have equal width, gaps between bars are equal, the scale must be uniform, and the height of each bar represents the value.
Rule 4: Data can be read directly from a graph (reading values) or interpreted (comparing, finding totals, differences, highest, lowest).
Rule 5: The scale of a bar graph should be chosen so that all values can be represented clearly — usually the largest value determines the scale.

questions.question_text: In tally marks, the number 7 is represented as:

options.text: One group of five (with a diagonal) and two vertical strokes
One group of five and three vertical strokes

questions.explanation_correct: In tally marks, every fifth mark is a diagonal through the first four. So 7 = one bundle of 5 (four vertical + one diagonal) plus 2 more vertical strokes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tally marks are grouped in fives. 7 = 5 + 2, which is one group of five and two additional vertical strokes.

questions.question_text: A frequency table shows:

options.text: How often each item or value occurs

questions.explanation_correct: A frequency table records how many times (the frequency) each item, category, or value appears in the data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency means 'how often something occurs'. A frequency table shows the count of each category or value in the data.

questions.question_text: The tally marks |||| || represent the number:
questions.explanation_correct: |||| is a group of 5 (four vertical with a diagonal) and || is 2 more. Total = 5 + 2 = 7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One group of 5 tally marks plus 2 individual marks = 7.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, if one picture of a book represents 10 books, then 3 pictures represent:
questions.explanation_correct: Each picture = 10 books. So 3 pictures = 3 x 10 = 30 books.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key says 1 picture = 10 books. So 3 pictures = 3 x 10 = 30 books.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, the key states: one symbol = 5 students. To show 15 students, how many symbols are needed?
questions.explanation_correct: Number of symbols = 15 ÷ 5 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each symbol represents 5 students. To show 15 students: 15 ÷ 5 = 3 symbols.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, all bars must have:
questions.explanation_correct: In a bar graph, all bars must have equal width. The height varies according to the data values. There should be equal gaps between bars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graphs require equal-width bars with equal spacing. Heights vary to represent different data values.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, the height of each bar represents the frequency or value of that category.
questions.explanation_correct: The height (or length for horizontal bar graphs) of each bar shows the numerical value or frequency for that category.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is a defining feature of bar graphs — the bar height is proportional to the data value it represents.

questions.question_text: In tally marks, each group of five is shown by four vertical strokes crossed by one ______ stroke.
questions.explanation_correct: The fifth tally mark is a diagonal stroke drawn across the four vertical strokes, creating a bundle of five.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The standard tally system uses a diagonal (slanting) line across four vertical marks to represent five.

questions.question_text: To find which category has the highest value in a bar graph, you look for the:
questions.explanation_correct: In a bar graph, the tallest bar represents the category with the highest value, since bar height is proportional to value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All bars have equal width, so the tallest bar has the highest value.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, half a symbol represents:

options.text: Half the value that one full symbol represents

questions.explanation_correct: A half symbol represents half the value of a full symbol. For example, if 1 symbol = 10, half a symbol = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Partial symbols in pictographs represent proportional values. Half symbol = half the key value.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is essential in every bar graph?

options.text: A title and labels for both axes

questions.explanation_correct: Every bar graph must have a title, labels for both axes (categories and values), and a consistent scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A proper bar graph needs a title, axis labels, and a scale. Without these, the reader cannot interpret the data.

questions.question_text: The tally marks |||| |||| ||| represent:
questions.explanation_correct: Two groups of 5 = 10, plus 3 more strokes = 13.

questions.question_text: What does 'interpreting data' mean?

options.text: Drawing conclusions and answering questions based on data

questions.explanation_correct: Interpreting data means analysing the information presented (in tables, graphs, etc.) to draw conclusions, compare values, and answer questions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interpretation goes beyond just collecting or organizing data. It means making sense of the data by drawing conclusions and answering questions.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, the scale on the y-axis must always start from 0.
questions.explanation_correct: For accurate visual comparison, the scale on the value axis (usually y-axis) of a bar graph should start from 0. Otherwise, bar heights can be misleading.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starting the scale from 0 ensures that bar heights accurately represent the data proportionally.

questions.question_text: Which is the first step in data handling?
questions.explanation_correct: The first step is collecting data (through surveys, observations, experiments). Then it is organized, represented, and interpreted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data handling follows this order: collect → organize → represent (tables, graphs) → interpret. Collection comes first.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph with key: 1 apple symbol = 4 apples, how many apples does 2 and a half symbols represent?
questions.explanation_correct: 2 full symbols = 2 x 4 = 8 apples. Half symbol = 4 ÷ 2 = 2 apples. Total = 8 + 2 = 10 apples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2.5 symbols x 4 apples per symbol = 10 apples.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the number of students in different clubs: Art = 25, Music = 30, Sports = 45, Science = 35. Which club has the most students?
questions.explanation_correct: Sports has 45 students, which is the highest among all clubs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Comparing: Art = 25, Music = 30, Science = 35, Sports = 45. Sports has the most.

questions.question_text: In a survey, 30 students were asked their favourite fruit. Results: Apple = 8, Mango = 12, Banana = 6, Orange = 4. What is the frequency of Mango?
questions.explanation_correct: The frequency of Mango is 12, meaning 12 students chose Mango as their favourite fruit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency is the number of times a particular value appears. Mango was chosen by 12 students, so its frequency is 12.

questions.question_text: A class recorded the number of siblings each student has: 0, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2. The frequency of '1 sibling' is:
questions.explanation_correct: Count the number of 1s in the data: 0, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2. The value 1 appears 4 times.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Count: 1 appears at positions 2, 4, 6, 9. That is 4 times, so the frequency is 4.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows the number of cars sold: Week 1 has 4 car symbols, Week 2 has 6 car symbols. Key: 1 car symbol = 5 cars. How many more cars were sold in Week 2 than Week 1?
questions.explanation_correct: Week 1: 4 x 5 = 20 cars. Week 2: 6 x 5 = 30 cars. Difference = 30 - 20 = 10 cars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Week 2 has 2 more symbols than Week 1. Each symbol = 5 cars. Difference = 2 x 5 = 10 cars.

questions.question_text: A bar graph uses a scale where 1 unit on the y-axis = 10 students. A bar reaches up to the 4th gridline. How many students does it represent?
questions.explanation_correct: Each gridline = 10 students. The bar reaches the 4th gridline = 4 x 10 = 40 students.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scale: 1 unit = 10 students. Bar at 4th gridline = 4 x 10 = 40 students.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows rainfall (in mm) for 4 months: Jan = 20, Feb = 15, Mar = 30, Apr = 25. The total rainfall for these months is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all values: 20 + 15 + 30 + 25 = 90 mm.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, key: 1 tree symbol = 20 trees. How many symbols are needed to represent 90 trees?
questions.explanation_correct: 90 ÷ 20 = 4.5. So 4 full symbols and 1 half symbol are needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90 ÷ 20 = 4.5, which means 4 full symbols and 1 half symbol.

questions.question_text: The highest value in a data set is 120. What would be a good scale for the y-axis of a bar graph?
questions.explanation_correct: With 1 unit = 20, the graph goes up to 120/20 = 6 gridlines, which is a practical and readable scale. 1 unit = 1 would need 120 gridlines (too many), and 1 unit = 100 would only have about 1 gridline (too few).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The scale should make the graph readable. 1 unit = 20 gives 6 gridlines for 120, which is clear and practical.

questions.question_text: A frequency table shows: Red = 15, Blue = 10, Green = 8, Yellow = 7. How many items were surveyed in total?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sum all frequencies: 15 + 10 + 8 + 7 = 40.

questions.question_text: In a class survey, the following data was collected for favourite sport: Cricket, Football, Cricket, Tennis, Cricket, Football, Cricket, Tennis, Football, Cricket. The frequency of Cricket is:
questions.explanation_correct: Count Cricket in the list: positions 1, 3, 5, 7, 10. That is 5 occurrences.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Count: Cricket appears at positions 1, 3, 5, 7, 10 = 5 times.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph with key '1 symbol = 8 items', three-quarter of a symbol represents 6 items.
questions.explanation_correct: Three-quarters of 8 = (3/4) x 8 = 6 items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: (3/4) of 8 = 6 items. Partial symbols represent proportional values.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, the bar for City A reaches 35 on the y-axis and the bar for City B reaches 50. The difference in their values is:
questions.explanation_correct: Difference = 50 - 35 = 15.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Subtract the smaller value from the larger: 50 - 35 = 15.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows marks obtained by 5 students: Anu = 80, Bina = 65, Charu = 90, Dev = 75, Ela = 85. Who scored the least?
questions.explanation_correct: Bina scored 65, which is the lowest among all five students.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compare: 80, 65, 90, 75, 85. The lowest is 65 (Bina).

questions.question_text: If the tally marks for a category show |||| |||| |||| ||, the frequency is ______.
questions.explanation_correct: Three groups of 5 = 15, plus 2 more = 17.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows oranges sold on different days. Monday: 3 symbols, Tuesday: 5 symbols, Wednesday: 4 symbols, Thursday: 2 symbols. Key: 1 symbol = 6 oranges. On which day were the most oranges sold?
questions.explanation_correct: Tuesday has the most symbols (5), so the most oranges were sold on Tuesday: 5 x 6 = 30 oranges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The day with the most symbols has the most oranges. Tuesday has 5 symbols (= 30 oranges), more than any other day.

questions.question_text: A pictograph needs to show 35 trees. Key: 1 tree symbol = 10 trees. How should this be represented?

options.text: 3 full symbols and a half symbol

questions.explanation_correct: 35 ÷ 10 = 3.5, so 3 full symbols and 1 half symbol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 35 ÷ 10 = 3.5. This is shown as 3 full symbols and a half symbol.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the number of books read by 4 students: Priya = 12, Qasim = 8, Riya = 15, Samir = 10. What is the average number of books read?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average = sum ÷ number of students = 45 ÷ 4 = 11.25.

questions.question_text: A bar graph can be drawn with horizontal bars instead of vertical bars.
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs can have vertical bars or horizontal bars. Both are valid representations. In horizontal bar graphs, the length of the bar represents the value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both vertical and horizontal bar graphs are correct. The orientation does not change the data represented.

questions.question_text: Anita surveyed 40 students about their favourite subject. She made a frequency table: Maths = 12, Science = 10, English = 8, Hindi = ?. What is the frequency of Hindi?
questions.explanation_incorrect: All frequencies must add up to the total surveyed (40). Hindi = 40 - 12 - 10 - 8 = 10.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows production of a factory. Key: 1 symbol = 100 units. Monday: 5 symbols, Tuesday: 3.5 symbols, Wednesday: 4 symbols. What is the total production?
questions.explanation_correct: Monday: 5 x 100 = 500. Tuesday: 3.5 x 100 = 350. Wednesday: 4 x 100 = 400. Total = 500 + 350 + 400 = 1,250 units.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the temperature of a city over 5 days: Mon = 30°C, Tue = 32°C, Wed = 28°C, Thu = 35°C, Fri = 31°C. On how many days was the temperature above 30°C?
questions.explanation_correct: Days above 30°C: Tuesday (32), Thursday (35), Friday (31). That is 3 days.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Above 30°C means > 30: Tue (32), Thu (35), Fri (31) = 3 days. Monday at exactly 30 is not above 30.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the population of 4 villages: A = 800, B = 1200, C = 600, D = 1000. Village B has how many more people than Village C?
questions.explanation_correct: Difference = 1200 - 600 = 600 people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Village B (1200) - Village C (600) = 600.

questions.question_text: A teacher recorded the shoe sizes of 20 students. The data is: 5, 6, 5, 7, 6, 5, 6, 7, 8, 5, 6, 7, 5, 6, 7, 8, 6, 5, 7, 6. Which shoe size has the highest frequency?
questions.explanation_correct: Count: 5 appears 6 times, 6 appears 7 times, 7 appears 5 times, 8 appears 2 times. Size 6 has the highest frequency (7).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Counting each: size 5 = 6 times, size 6 = 7 times, size 7 = 5 times, size 8 = 2 times. Size 6 is the most frequent.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows visitors to a museum. Key: 1 person symbol = 50 visitors. Monday has 3 symbols, Tuesday has 5 symbols, Wednesday has 2.5 symbols. How many total visitors came in these 3 days?
questions.explanation_correct: Total symbols = 3 + 5 + 2.5 = 10.5. Total visitors = 10.5 x 50 = 525.

questions.question_text: Kavya needs to draw a bar graph for the following data: Maths = 95, Science = 80, English = 70, Hindi = 85. She uses a scale of 1 unit = 10 marks. The bar for Science will be how many units tall?
questions.explanation_correct: Science = 80 marks. At scale 1 unit = 10 marks, bar height = 80 ÷ 10 = 8 units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar height = value ÷ scale = 80 ÷ 10 = 8 units.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the number of trees in 4 parks: Park P = 50, Park Q = 75, Park R = 60, Park S = 45. The parks are to be arranged in decreasing order of trees. Which is the correct order?
questions.explanation_correct: Decreasing order: Q (75) > R (60) > P (50) > S (45). Answer: Q, R, P, S.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arrange from highest to lowest: 75 (Q), 60 (R), 50 (P), 45 (S) → Q, R, P, S.

questions.question_text: A frequency table for dice throws shows: 1 = 4, 2 = 6, 3 = 5, 4 = 3, 5 = 7, 6 = 5. How many times was the dice thrown in total?
questions.explanation_correct: Total throws = 4 + 6 + 5 + 3 + 7 + 5 = 30.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all frequencies: 4 + 6 + 5 + 3 + 7 + 5 = 30.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows monthly sales: Jan = 200, Feb = 300, Mar = 250, Apr = 350. In which month did sales increase the most compared to the previous month?
questions.explanation_correct: Jan to Feb: increase of 100. Feb to Mar: decrease of 50. Mar to Apr: increase of 100. February saw the first increase of 100 (from 200 to 300), which ties with April's increase. But February is listed first and the increase from Jan to Feb is 100 = same as Mar to Apr. The answer is February as it appears first with the largest increase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increases: Jan→Feb = +100, Feb→Mar = -50, Mar→Apr = +100. February and April both increased by 100, but February is the first such month.

questions.question_text: Which type of graph is best for comparing quantities across different categories?
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs are ideal for comparing quantities across different categories because the bar heights make differences visually clear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pie charts show parts of a whole, line graphs show trends over time, and scatter plots show relationships. Bar graphs are best for comparing discrete categories.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph about ice cream sales, the key says 1 cone symbol = 20 cones. Chocolate flavour shows 7 full symbols and a half symbol. How many chocolate cones were sold?
questions.explanation_correct: 7.5 symbols x 20 = 150 cones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 full + 0.5 = 7.5 symbols. 7.5 x 20 = 150 cones.

questions.question_text: A frequency table shows the number of students scoring in different ranges: 0-20: 3 students, 21-40: 7 students, 41-60: 12 students, 61-80: 10 students, 81-100: 8 students. How many students scored more than 60?
questions.explanation_correct: Students scoring more than 60 = those in 61-80 range + those in 81-100 range = 10 + 8 = 18.

questions.question_text: A bar graph with a scale of 1 unit = 5 can exactly represent the value 23.
questions.explanation_correct: With a scale of 1 unit = 5, the gridlines are at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, etc. The value 23 falls between 20 and 25, so it cannot be read exactly from the gridlines (though it can be approximately shown).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 23 is not a multiple of 5, so it would fall between gridlines and cannot be represented exactly on this scale.

questions.question_text: Ravi collected data on the colours of 50 cars in a parking lot. He used tally marks and found: White = 18, Black = 12, Red = 8, Blue = ?, Silver = 5. How many blue cars were there?
questions.explanation_incorrect: All frequencies must add to 50. Blue = 50 - 18 - 12 - 8 - 5 = 7.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows the number of students in different sections: A = 40, B = 35, C = 45, D = 30. If 5 students move from section C to section D, what will the new values be for C and D?
questions.explanation_correct: C loses 5: 45 - 5 = 40. D gains 5: 30 + 5 = 35. New values: C = 40, D = 35.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 5 students move from C to D: C = 45 - 5 = 40, D = 30 + 5 = 35.
